The reason you all can hear the Shepard tone restarting is simply because it wasn't made very well. If you use more tones at the same time, and mess around with the envelope (fade in, fade out), it will work properly. Go find other versions - eventually one will work on you. If you're interested in auditory illusions, I suggest you check out the 'Gap Transfer Illusion', and other awesome auditory illusions that were discovered by Yoshitaka Nakajima (et al), who specializes in auditory illusions. In fact, here is the demonstration page from the University lab:

http://www.design.kyushu-u.ac.jp/~ynhome/ENG/Demo/2nd/01.html#01

Cheers, and happy listening.

That sound is kind of easy to make. I make maps for Garry's Mod, Counter-Strike: Source and Half-Life: Source and I add ambient music to my maps. Instead of adding an entire song, I pic a piece of the song and loop it almost perfectly. Kind of like Canon in D, or The Entertainer, I take a 10 to 20 second section of the music, fade out the last 1 - .5 seconds of that song, Ctrl + X it and Paste over the beginning, creating the illusion of a looping tune. I guess that's kind of similar to that sound that never stops up-pitching.

To those who are saying that they can hear this or that and don't hear it rising, it's only because now, you have discovered the truth. I know about this from a long, long time (probably longer than this video has existed) but it tricks me as well. And that is very natural. While it doesn't pitch up but it certainly does create a rising effect and this trick has been used ever since music and sound has existed. Believe it or not but many sound effects are still created this way and helps a lot of time while sound design/designing. Similar method is also used to create a natural and infinite loop of a sound. This is a very effective technique but seems to have been lost amongst other numerous methods of sound design which are also very lengthy.
